00029 
00030 /*
00031    Scanner for the DAS. This file works with gnu's flex scanner generator. It
00032    returns either ATTR, ID, VAL, TYPE or one of the single character tokens
00033    `{', `}', `;', `,' or `\n' as integers. In the case of an ID or VAL, the
00034    scanner stores a pointer to the lexeme in yylval (whose type is char *).
00035 
00036    The scanner discards all comment text.
00037 
00038    The scanner returns quoted strings as VALs. Any characters may appear in a
00039    quoted string except backslash (\) and quote("). To include these escape
00040    them with a backslash.
00041    
00042    The scanner is not reentrant, but can share name spaces with other
00043    scanners.
00044    
00045    Note:
00046    1) The `defines' file das.tab.h is built using `bison -d'.
00047    2) Define YY_DECL such that the scanner is called `daslex'.
00048    3) When bison builds the das.tab.h file, it uses `das' instead of `yy' for
00049    variable name prefixes (e.g., yylval --> daslval).
00050    4) The quote stuff is very complicated because we want backslash (\)
00051    escapes to work and because we want line counts to work too. In order to
00052    properly scan a quoted string two C functions are used: one to remove the
00053    escape characters from escape sequences and one to remove the trailing
00054    quote on the end of the string. 
00055 
00056    jhrg 7/12/94 
00057 
00058    NB: We don't remove the \'s or ending quotes any more -- that way the
00059    printed das can be reparsed. 9/28/94. 
00060 */
00061 
00062 %{
00063 #include "config_dap.h"
00064 
00065 static char rcsid[] not_used ={"$Id$"};
00066 
00067 #include <string.h>
00068 
00069 #include "debug.h"
00070 #include "parser.h"
00071 
00072 /* These defines must precede the das.tab.h include. */
00073 #define YYSTYPE char *
00074 #define YY_DECL int daslex YY_PROTO(( void ))
00075 
00076 #include "das.tab.h"
00077 
00078 int das_line_num = 1;
00079 static int start_line;      /* used in quote and comment error handlers */
00080 
00081 %}
00082     
00083 %option noyywrap
00084 %x quote
00085 %x comment
00086 
00087 ATTR    attributes|Attributes|ATTRIBUTES
00088 
00089 ALIAS   ALIAS|Alias|alias
00090 BYTE    BYTE|Byte|byte
00091 INT16   INT16|Int16|int16
00092 UINT16  UINT16|UInt16|Uint16|uint16
00093 INT32   INT32|Int32|int32
00094 UINT32  UINT32|UInt32|Uint32|uint32
00095 FLOAT32 FLOAT32|Float32|float32
00096 FLOAT64 FLOAT64|Float64|float64
00097 STRING  STRING|String|string
00098 URL URL|Url|url
00099 
00100 /* Comment chars (#) are treated specially. Lets hope nobody wants to start
00101    A variable name with one... Note that the DAS allows Identifiers to have 
00102    parens and colons while the DDS and expr scanners don't. It's too hard to
00103    disambiguate functions when IDs have parens in them and adding colons
00104    makes parsing the array projections hard. 10/31/2001 jhrg */
00105 
00106 WORD    [-+a-zA-Z0-9_/%.:\\()*][-+a-zA-Z0-9_/%.:\\()#*]*
00107 
00108 NEVER   [^\-+a-zA-Z0-9_/%.:\\()#{};,[\]]
00109 
00110 %%
00111 
00112 {ATTR}                  daslval = yytext; return SCAN_ATTR;
00113 
00114 {ALIAS}                 daslval = yytext; return SCAN_ALIAS;
00115 {BYTE}                  daslval = yytext; return SCAN_BYTE;
00116 {INT16}                 daslval = yytext; return SCAN_INT16;
00117 {UINT16}                daslval = yytext; return SCAN_UINT16;
00118 {INT32}                 daslval = yytext; return SCAN_INT32;
00119 {UINT32}                daslval = yytext; return SCAN_UINT32;
00120 {FLOAT32}               daslval = yytext; return SCAN_FLOAT32;
00121 {FLOAT64}               daslval = yytext; return SCAN_FLOAT64;
00122 {STRING}                daslval = yytext; return SCAN_STRING;
00123 {URL}                   daslval = yytext; return SCAN_URL;
00124 
00125 {WORD}                  {
00126                 daslval = yytext; 
00127                 DBG(cerr << "WORD: " << yytext << endl); 
00128                 return SCAN_WORD;
00129             }
00130 
00131 "{"                     return (int)*yytext;
00132 "}"                     return (int)*yytext;
00133 ";"                     return (int)*yytext;
00134 ","                     return (int)*yytext;
00135 
00136 [ \t\r]+
00137 \n                  ++das_line_num;
00138 <INITIAL><<EOF>>        yy_init = 1; das_line_num = 1; yyterminate();
00139 
00140 "#"                 BEGIN(comment);
00141 <comment>[^\r\n]*
00142 <comment>\n     ++das_line_num; BEGIN(INITIAL);
00143 <comment>\r\n       ++das_line_num; BEGIN(INITIAL);
00144 <comment><<EOF>>        yy_init = 1; das_line_num = 1; yyterminate();
00145 
00146 \"          BEGIN(quote); start_line = das_line_num; yymore();
00147 <quote>[^"\r\n\\]*  yymore();
00148 <quote>[^"\r\n\\]*\n    yymore(); ++das_line_num;
00149 <quote>[^"\r\n\\]*\r\n  yymore(); ++das_line_num;
00150 <quote>\\.      yymore();
00151 <quote>\"       { 
00152                   BEGIN(INITIAL); 
00153 
00154               daslval = yytext;
00155 
00156               return SCAN_WORD;
00157                         }
00158 <quote><<EOF>>      {
00159                           char msg[256];
00160               sprintf(msg,
00161                   "Unterminated quote (starts on line %d)\n",
00162                   start_line);
00163               YY_FATAL_ERROR(msg);
00164                         }
00165 
00166 {NEVER}                 {
00167                           if (yytext) { /* suppress msgs about `' chars */
00168                             fprintf(stderr, "Character `%c' is not", *yytext);
00169                             fprintf(stderr, " allowed (except within");
00170                 fprintf(stderr, " quotes) and has been ignored\n");
00171               }
00172             }
00173 %%

00194  *
00195  * Revision 1.30.4.6  2002/06/11 00:40:52  jimg
00196  * I added '*' to the set of characters allowed in a WORD in both the DAS
00197  * and DDS scanners. It's not allowed in the expr scanner because that
00198  * would cause conflicts with the URL dereference operator.
00199  *
00200  * Revision 1.34  2002/06/03 22:21:15  jimg
00201  * Merged with release-3-2-9
00202  *
00203  * Revision 1.30.4.5  2001/11/01 00:43:51  jimg
00204  * Fixes to the scanners and parsers so that dataset variable names may
00205  * start with digits. I've expanded the set of characters that may appear
00206  * in a variable name and made it so that all except `#' may appear at
00207  * the start. Some characters are not allowed in variables that appear in
00208  * a DDS or CE while they are allowed in the DAS. This makes it possible
00209  * to define containers with names like `COARDS:long_name.' Putting a colon
00210  * in a variable name makes the CE parser much more complex. Since the set
00211  * of characters that people want seems pretty limited (compared to the
00212  * complete ASCII set) I think this is an OK approach. If we have to open
00213  * up the expr.lex scanner completely, then we can but not without adding
00214  * lots of action clauses to teh parser. Note that colon is just an example,
00215  * there's a host of characters that are used in CEs that are not allowed
00216  * in IDs.
00217  *

00351  * Fixed a problem with quoted strings - previously quotes were stripped
00352  * when scanned, but this caused problems when they were printed because
00353  * the printed string could not be recanned. In addition, escape characters
00354  * are no longer removed during scanning. The functions that performed these
00355  * operations are still in the scanner, but their calls have been commented
00356  * out.

00373  * method using a global instance variable.
